title: 106_hr809
content:
The "Federal Protective Service Reform Act of 2000" designates police officers and amends the Act of June 1, 1948 by replacing "special policemen" with "police officers" and updating terminology. The Act of June 1, 1948 is further amended to grant additional powers to police officers, including the authority to carry firearms, petition Federal courts for warrants, and make warrantless arrests under certain circumstances. The Act of June 1, 1948 is amended to grant additional powers to police officers, including conducting investigations of offenses against property under the charge of the Administrator. These powers become effective after regulations are issued by the Commissioner of the Federal Protective Service and approved by the Attorney General. The Administrator may also enter into agreements with State and local governments for additional authority outside federal property. The Act of June 1, 1948 is amended to grant police officers appointed under this section the authority to exercise powers in areas adjacent to property owned by the United States. This includes conducting investigations of offenses against property under the charge of the Administrator. SEC. 4. PENALTIES.

Amends the Act of June 1, 1948 to impose fines or imprisonment for violating regulations, with a maximum penalty of a Class C misdemeanor.

SEC. 5. SPECIAL AGENTS.

Amends the Act of June 1, 1948 to replace "nonuniformed special policemen" with "special agents" and grants special agents the same authority as police officers outside Federal property. Establishment of Federal Protective Service under the Act of June 1, 1948, with added provisions for penalties and special agents. The Federal Protective Service is established as a separate operating service of the General Services Administration. It is headed by a Commissioner appointed by the Administrator with at least 5 years of law enforcement experience. The Commissioner assists in carrying out duties under the Act and serves as the law enforcement officer and security official of the United States. The Federal Protective Service, headed by a Commissioner with law enforcement experience, is responsible for protecting Federal officers and employees in US-owned buildings. They provide assistance to other law enforcement agencies and coordinate activities with the Commissioner of the Public Buildings Service. This does not affect the duties of the United States Secret Service. Regional Directors and Assistant Directors are appointed under this service. The Commissioner of the Federal Protective Service may appoint regional directors and assistant commissioners with specific law enforcement experience requirements. The pay level of the Commissioner is specified in the United States Code. SEC. 7. PAY AND BENEFITS. The Act of June 1, 1948 is amended to include provisions for pay and benefits. SEC. 7. PAY AND BENEFITS. The pay and benefits for Federal Protective Service employees with active law enforcement status will be equivalent to those of United States Capitol Police members, effective January 1, 2001. Additional compensation is authorized. SEC. 8. NUMBER OF POLICE OFFICERS. After a 1-year period, there must be at least 730 full-time police officers in the Federal Protective Service, which cannot be reduced without specific authorization by law. SEC. 9. EMPLOYMENT STANDARDS AND TRAINING. The Commissioner of the Federal Protective Service will set minimum employment standards for security personnel contracted for U.S. government-owned buildings under the Administrator of General Services. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. The Act of June 1, 1948 is further amended to authorize appropriations from the Federal Buildings Fund for carrying out the Act.
